intro: Loranthus gabonensis, commonly known as the Gabon mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches itself to the branches of host trees, primarily in the rainforests of Central and West Africa. It lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients from its host through specialized structures called haustoria. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers and red berries that are dispersed by birds. Its leaves are usually alternate and have a leathery texture. Loranthus gabonensis plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat, influencing host tree health and providing food for various wildlife species.
